{"blocks":[{"key":"drhfq","text":"Processing human frontal cortex brain tissue for population-scale Oxford Nanopore long-read DNA sequencing SOP","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":110}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1mlcn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ddjg","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"acit6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9av5r","text":"LIbrary preparation for population-scale Oxford Nanopore long-read DNA sequencing SOP


At the NIH's Center for Alzheimer's and Related Dementias (CARD) https://card.nih.gov/research-programs/long-read-sequencing we will generate long-read sequencing data from thousands of patients with Alzheimer's disease, frontotemporal dementia, Lewy body dementia, and healthy subjects. With this research, we will build a public resource consisting of long-read genome sequencing data from a large number of confirmed people with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias and healthy individuals. To generate this large-scale nanopore sequencing data we have developed a protocol for processing and long-read sequencing human frontal cortex brain tissue, targeting an N50 of  ~30kb and ~30X coverage.   


†Correspondence to: Kimberley Billingsley billingsleykj@nih.gov


Acknowledgements:
We would like to thank the Nanopore team (Androo Markham & Jessica Anderson) and the whole CARD long-read team listed below => UCSC: Benedict Paten, Trevor Pesout, Paolo Carnevali, Mira Mastoras, Melissa Meredith, Jean Monlong, Ryan Lorig-Roach, Mobin Asri; NE: Miten Jain; NCI: Mikhail Kolmogorov; NHGRI: Adam Phillippy, Arang Rhie; Baylor: Fritz Sedlazeck, Farhang Jaryani; JHU: Winston Timp; NIA: Cornelis Blauwendraat, Kimberley Billingsley, Pilar Alvarez Jerez, Laksh Malik, Breeana Baker, Maysa Abdelhalim, Kensuke Daida, Rylee Genner,  Abigail Miano-Burkhardt, Caroline Pantazis;","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":153,"length":59},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":838,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":153,"length":59},{"key":1,"offset":838,"length":21}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"BC6B6DE3323A11EE98500A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://card.nih.gov/research-programs/long-read-sequencing"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"BC6B6E25323A11EE98500A58A9FEAC02","url":null}}}}

Ideally, the library quants yielded at least 540ng to allow for 3 x 180ng loads, the latter 2 loaded approximately after 24 and 48 hours. However this will vary slightly depending on pore usage, data generated, as well as other factors (i.e. if after 24 hours there are still 3000+ pores then the sample does not need to be reloaded until 48 hours).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1is2g","text":"To wash and reload a flow cell, begin by thawing Wash Mix (WMX) on ice and Wash Diluent (DIL) at RT","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5pt05","text":"Note: DIL should be vortexed. WMX should NOT be vortexed, only spun","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"97a0b","text":"In a new tube, add   WMX to   DIL and pipette mix. This is your flow cell wash mix. 1.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c7nmh","text":"Using a P1000, insert tip into inlet port 1 and draw back a small volume using the tip).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"btpmk","text":"Load   flow cell wash mix into inlet port 1, avoiding any introduction of {"blocks":[{"key":"36m4m","text":"Part 4. Pre-Shear DNA Quantification(~3 hours for 8 samples)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":60}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"di415","text":"Hand-shear 10X with 1mL Luer-Lock syringes and 1.5” needles (bringing sample up into needle and depressing plunger counts as 1 cycle).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cnamk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ahna4","text":"Note: This step isn't to shear the DNA to a specific size, it is required to get an accurate QC reading for downstream processes. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bif2","text":"Quantify using the Qubit Flex Fluorometer. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c7tji","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2a9fo","text":"Note: Taking top-middle-bottom Qubit measurements may be useful for new cohorts. If the measurements vary greatly, extra hand-shearing may be necessary.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6h11d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5pq4v","text":"Note: If the Qubit concentrations are lower than expected, repeat the extraction from Part 3.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"biubm","text":"Obtain tissue samples from the -80°C freezer and place them into the ice bucket. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3ti8q","text":"Wear all necessary protective equipment (lab coat, face shield and/or mask, gloves) and complete the following steps in a chemical fume hood.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8oiro","text":"Dispose of used weighing boat in a burn box and razor blade in the sharps waste container between each sample to prevent inter-sample contamination. Keep all tissue samples on dry ice when not in use.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4pgjh","text":"Weigh the labeled empty 2ml tube to tare the scale, ensuring that the tube is centered. Then, place the chilled weigh boat on top of the cooling block.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7ib6s","text":"Using the right hand to grip the blade and left hand to shield any flying pieces, cut the brain tissue.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fovsm","text":"Lift the cut tissue piece, transfer to the chilled labeled empty tube, and weigh immediately. Place it back on the dry ice immediately to avoid tissue thawing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"m4tg","text":"Add or remove tissue using the method outlined above as required by input specifications. Each brain region yields slightly different extraction results so input amounts may need to be optimized per region. In our experience frontal cortex, parietal cortex, and visual cortex require ~35mg-45mg however for cerebellum less input is required (8-10mg).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2m038","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2a6rn","text":"Note: DNA recovery varies based on amount of gray matter vs. white matter.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"3ri52","text":"Put on a  2nd pair of gloves.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":11,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2h5e2","text":"Discard the top layer of gloves and place in a burn box. Repeat Steps 1.4 to 1.11 for subsequent brain samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"sl4j","text":"In a chemical fume hood, submerge the TissueRuptor probe tip into the buffer and blend at a max speed for ~10s (place probe tip off to side to be cleaned later if desired).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9c902","text":"Transfer the homogenate to a 2 mL Protein LoBind tube(or same original tube from before) including all undisrupted tissue chunks and any foam that forms. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5faen","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"81qrk","text":"Note: It may be better to quickly pour the liquid portion of the homogenate into the 2ml tube and use a wide-bore P1000 pipette to transfer the foam. Since it takes a while for the foam to dispense out of the tip, it may be better to set the pipette to ~  and quickly remove smaller portions so that the 2ml tube does not warm up too much. If the 2ml tube starts to warm up, place it on the wet ice and continue removing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":254,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"400","error":false,"guid":"15D34A302A4611EE907F31D95CBA0445","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6edou","text":"Add   Buffer SB and vortex for  at maximum speed.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":4,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":31,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e2g0f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"50","error":false,"guid":"200C5DB02A4711EE907F31D95CBA0445","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"1":{"type":"duration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"duration":10,"guid":"1FF22B702AF611EEA661BDE853AA642D","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2ha5o","text":"Size on the Agilent Tapestation 4200 or prepare separate DNA dilutions(0.005 - 0.5ng/ul) and size using the Agilent Femto Pulse. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"40h0k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3s0vq","text":"Note: Samples can be sized at any stage during the QC process(i.e. post-extraction, post-size selection, post-BluePippin, and post-Megaruptor shearing).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"25hgk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d1e2q","text":"Note: Depending on the nature of the cohort, post-extraction peaks can range between 45-120kb and be heterogeneous. If the Femto does not yield desired peak sizes, repeat the extraction from Part 3. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9bsf4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2fabo","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"br3bk","text":"Note:  It is recommended to use the Femto Pulse System to get a better representation of the size distribution of the DNA samples. {"blocks":[{"key":"dv4e7","text":"Part 5: DNA Size Selection (1.5 hours for 8 samples)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":52}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cekit","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fqjqp","text":"Note: This process can be done before or after Megaruptor shearing depending on the nature of the cohort. cells)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":2},{"style":"bold","offset":3,"length":71}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"pin6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5vflh","text":"Following the completion of the sequencing, flow cells may be removed from the sequencer.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a63n1","text":"Place enough absorbent material to take up approximately 4 mL of flush waste.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5oest","text":"Rotate valve to reveal inlet port 1.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"425on","text":"Place flow cell at a 45° angle on the absorbent material and, using a P1000, flush 1 mL of DI water into the inlet port.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fgepf","text":"Repeat 3 more times for a total of 4 mL.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"11urp","text":"Once complete, close the inlet port cover and remove all liquid from the waste port.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ahd84","text":"Dispose of absorbent material as local biological waste guidelines
